author: muesliswap
title: Secure off-chain community voting
description: Voting protocols with astonishing security properties have long been a topic in cryptography. For Cardano off-chain voting systems no implementations of such perfectly suited systems are available.

f6_assessments.q0: I agree with proposers that right now in Cardano there are neither off-chain voting systems, nor implementations of such systems. This proposal seems to be able to enable the formation of DAO structures for many projects in the ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1: The team behind this proposal is very experienced - OpenSwap Technologies - created MuesliSwap, one of the biggest decentralised apps on Cardano. I used it personally several times. Moreover some team members have in-depth understanding of cryptography and deeper insight into the theoretical research that has been conducted on voting systems. This is very important as nowadays many people talk about DAO, many people want to earn money on DAO, but few people really understand cryptography and the technical aspects.
f6_assessments.q2: The budget of 51,750 USD is small comparing to 1 million USD of total budget. What I like is that budget is also written in details, which will help the aduit of this proposal if it’s successful. f6_assessments.q0:
I strongly agree that the proposal effectively addresses the challenge head on. The proposal communicates a solution to make DAO decision-making mechanisms more efficient. The OPEN-SOURCED nature of the proposal means that prospective organizations will have the tools necessary to thoroughly examine the features available on Cardano. These tools to organize community actions do not yet exist on Cardano. The proposal also took the time to highlight all the hallmarks of a person-centered project by putting emphasis on privacy, verifiability and many other factors important to the human users of these types of tools. This proposal is exciting. 

I want to highlight that the proposal’s communicated scope means that it will not DIRECTLY satisfy one of the campaign measures to increase the amount of transaction fees coming from DAO actions. But this should be celebrated.  And it should be noted that it can actually lead to way more participation, way more opportunities to vote, and therefore way more transaction fees (indirectly) related to DAO activities.
f6_assessments.q1: Based on what the proposer has communicated I strongly believe that the proposal is likely to be successfully implemented, and that the proposer has ample ability to solve the problems identified. The proposer identifies the type and number of team members that will successfully implement the project, and shows their relevant skills and experiences. There is a comprehensive budget outline that is broken out into appropriate terms that seem reasonable to achieve the goals. The proposal takes time to clearly explain the technical aspects that are crucial for implementation, all of which will be shared openly with the community. f6_assessments.q2: I believe that the proposal provides me with enough information to assess the progress in attaining set goals. The proposal does a great job if reinforcing the fact that the technical development will be observable and open sourced for the community to audit and even re-use. This is great. It goes on to explain that the findings from research phase will also be shared, and a survey conducted. This makes the entire process responsive to the inputs of the Cardano community. With that said, the proposer does not offer me a clear way to measure the targeted problems against the desired outcomes. But perhaps this is because there isn't such an elegant solution currently on Cardano.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposer makes a compelling argument for the value of off-chain voting solutions, particularly an open-source one. Even if off-chain voting isn't the answer for every governance model, having it as an option for DAOs will likely be valuable. 

While the Impact statements are sufficient as is, a few minor details could be improved. "Astonishing security properties" in the problem statement is a vague statement. Astonishing in what way? Good? Bad? Perplexing? I'd also like to see a deeper exploration of the need for both verifiability and receipt-freeness, since on the surface level those two goals seem to be at odds with each other. It doesn't need to be technical, but a 10,000 ft. view of how one might allow a vote to be verified for the voter, but not verifiable by a third party would be illuminating. 

Finally, while I appreciate the team's confidence--and they do have reason to be confident given their history--I am a little surprised to see no risks assessed for the project. There's no need for false modesty, of course, but voters may wonder if the proposer has a realistic appraisal of the situation, particularly if they're unfamiliar with the team's work. That said, the proposer's commitment to finishing the project even if it runs over budget is admirable.

It has long been argued for by various community members that we need a governance token and a new open source, decentralized tool-kit, not just for the Catalyst process, but any DAO creation or community. f6_assessments.q0:
The problem identified by this proposal is that no secure voting protocols have been implemented for Cardano yet. The team plans to fix this by developing an open-source off-chain voting solution that uses state of the art voting mechanisms and is specifically tailored for DAO structures on Cardano.  I believe this fits within the challenge as it is trying to provide tooling to support the development of any future DAOs on Cardano.

The proposal explains what properties their voting system will have and why those properties are valuable.  A few examples of some properties given are privacy, integrity, and verifiability. Not only do they explain why those properties would be useful, but also why an off chain solution is useful.  Off chain solutions allow for feeless voting, which in turn allows voting to be available for more people and for a greater frequency of elections.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team behind this proposal is the team behind Muesliswap, so they have experience developing on-chain and off-chain code for Cardano.  Additionally they state that several team members have an in-depth understanding of research around voting systems and cryptography, which will be useful for building a secure voting solution.

The team provides a three month timeline for delivering on this proposal.  Within that timeline they have well defined milestones with predictions of the amount of hours that will be spent on each milestone. This indicates they have a clear and well thought out plan for execution.

When asked about potential risks, the team states that there is a very little risk of not delivering considering the size and experience of the team behind this proposal.  They also state that running out of funds will not be an issue because if any unexpected expenses come up, the team will cover the extra costs.  This is because this tooling is something they themselves would like to use for Muesliswap, so they are highly interested in getting this developed.

They break down the budget into two categories: $11,250 for research and $40,500 for Development.  That’s where the breakdown ends. I think it would have been helpful to see the budget broken down even further to help the community evaluate if what they are asking for is reasonable.

Nevertheless, I think the team has provided enough evidence to believe that this proposal would likely be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2:
The team emphasizes that they want to be transparent throughout the entire process. Once the research phase has finished they plan to publish their findings in a survey paper where they go over the details of all the possible voting mechanisms they could use.  This will allow the public to see what progress has been made prior to the development phase.

Once the development phase begins, the team plans for all of their work to be publicly observable via GitHub. Combine this with clearly defined milestones in their roadmap, and you get a project that can be easily audited by anyone.

f6_assessments.q0:
In my not-so-humble opinion this is one of the very few submitted proposals in the challenge that actually address the challenge brief nicely. Yes, it is about making DAO tools, not DAOs! By providing their smart contract expertise from the successful DEX and UTxO order book mechanics, MuesliSwap promise to contribute Cardano infrastructure that can compete with Ethereum tooling. 
The proposers demonstrate a good understanding of the importance of DAOs for Cardano's Voltaire Era and offer a reasonable price tag for their services. In my opinion this proposal is highly effective in bringing DAOs on Cardano to the next level.
f6_assessments.q1: The MuesliSwap team are secretive about who is going to work on this exactly, but their popular DEX, appearances on Youtube and answering of questions from the community make me confident that we are paying for 690 high quality hours from people who know what they are doing and do not need to go our there and search for Plutus talent after they get funded. 90 hours are promised in high quality white paper writing and strategy, presumably by the founding members of MuesliSwap, so even partial outcomes of this proposal would be a welcome addition to the DAO capabilities of the Cardano ecosystem. The timeline appears to be a bit rushed, but as the hours are broken down in great detail, I am confident that enough development power will be allocated to the task, and I would be happy with the result even if there are a few delays. The proposal could have been written a little bit better, i.e. being more transparent and detailed, and not relying on the "brand name" of MuesliSwap alone. The deep thinking that went into the tasks required and the implications of Volatire do however compensate for this oversight / secrecy.
f6_assessments.q2: The community will be presented with a survey paper somewhat mid-way through the proposal and the development will be carried out as Open Source. Given the high exposure of the proposal team, I am confident that they will follow through on this promise and the community will be kept in the loop about the progress and success of this proposal. Auditing it given these promises would be possible. I would however have hoped for some more detail such as Github links or specific Discord channel to track the progress, not only because there are $50k of community funds requested, but also because this is a research area that should interest and excite a lot of community members, and would present an excellent opportunity for MuesliSwap team to feel the pulse of the community and tinker with their development directions accordingly - win / win.
